slides.title: Introduction to Policy Holds and Underwriting Referral Reasons
slides.notes: Introduction to the lesson focusing on policy holds and underwriting referral reasons in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to this lesson on policy holds and underwriting referral reasons in PolicyCenter. As we dive into these concepts, we'll explore how they impact policy transactions and the underwriting process. Understanding these elements is crucial for managing policy workflows effectively. Let's get started by examining the function of policy holds in maintaining accurate coverage forms and rates.

slides.title: Understanding Policy Holds
slides.notes: Policy holds overview with focus on the impact of state-level and nationwide changes.
slides.narration: Policy holds are essential in ensuring that policy transactions align with the most current rates and coverage forms. Changes often occur at the state level but can also be nationwide when multiple states adopt the same regulations. Policy holds temporarily pause work to prevent transactions from proceeding with outdated information, safeguarding the accuracy and compliance of policies.

slides.title: The Role of Policy Holds in Transactions
slides.notes: Details on how policy holds block transactions and create underwriting issues.
slides.narration: When a policy hold is in effect, all related policy transactions are blocked. PolicyCenter automatically generates an underwriting issue tied to the policy hold, signaling that the transaction cannot proceed. This mechanism ensures that any changes are thoroughly reviewed and approved before affecting the policy, maintaining the integrity of the underwriting process.

slides.title: Hold and Release a Transaction in PolicyCenter (Part 1)
slides.originalNotes:
Policy holds
For a business, coverage forms and rates are constantly changing. Changes are generally made at the state level by line of business. Although changes generally pertain to one state, sometimes changes occur on a nationwide level when numerous states adopt the same change simultaneously. Work is put on hold for a number of days before the effective date of the change to ensure that work is not started with incorrect rates or forms.

slides.narration: PolicyCenter uses a batch process called Policy Hold Job Evaluation to assess whether a hold can be lifted. This process runs at scheduled intervals, comparing current policy conditions against hold criteria. The PolicyHoldJobEvalPlugin plays a critical role here, tracking held transactions and updating their status. Once a hold is eligible for removal, an activity is generated, notifying the producer to proceed with the transaction.

slides.title: Policy Hold Lifecycle Management
slides.originalNotes:
Hold and release a transaction in PolicyCenter (I of 3)
Until the issue is approved, a batch process Policy Hold Job Evaluation runs at scheduled times and compares the period values with the hold values. It reevaluates whether the hold can be removed. An issue can be approved when the hold end date has passed, or the hold is modified by a superuser. The PolicyHoldJobEvalPlugin tracks transactions that are currently held by a policy hold and notes the last time the transaction was evaluated against the policy hold. Once a hold can be removed, an activity is sent to the producer so they can process the transaction.

slides.notes: Overview of underwriting referral reasons and their application.

Understanding how these reasons integrate with the overall policy lifecycle is crucial for developers aiming to optimize policy evaluation processes.

This automatic checking helps prevent policy discrepancies and maintains underwriting standards across all transactions.

slides.title: Real-World Application of Referral Reasons
slides.originalNotes:
Underwriting referral reasons
Referral reasons can be used to record underwriting issues for a policy outside of the context of a transaction. Since referral reasons are added to the policy, they can be created at any time, even when there is no policy transaction- PolicyCenter creates underwriting issuesfor these referral reasons the next time a user processes a transaction on the policy. It also checks for referral reasons at various point in the transaction progress. Referral reasons can block transaction progress on the policy. In the default application, the renewal transaction checks to see if there are any open referral reasons in the prior term. Referral reasons affect all transactions that handle underwriter issues.
Consider the following example for referral reason creation. An external claim system stores the loss claims for a policy. The external system notes that loss claims are unacceptably high. The external system sends a message to PolicyCenter to add an undemriting referral reason to the policy. The next time a transaction runs on the policy, an issue is created that corresponds to the referral reason which remains on the policy.

An underwriter cannot approve an underwriting referral reason, but the UW can remove it. For example, a visit to the customer site revealed numerous safety violations, and an underwriting referral reason was added to the policy- On a subsequent visit, the safety violations had been addressed- The underwriting referral reason is removed from the policy. The next time a transaction is run or reaches a checking set, the corresponding issue is deactivated-

questionData.question: Distinguish underwriting (UW) referral reasons from an UW issue.
questionData.answer: The underwriting referral reason is specific to a policy. When it generates an underwriting issue, the transaction will not progress further. UW referral reasons are often manually created, cannot be approved, and are manually deleted (or through an API). UW referral reasons persist with the policy. Underwriting issues are related to the transaction. When something is notable about this transaction requiring the attention of underwriting.
